clusters.neutral_headline: What we know about the joint US-Israel attack on Iran
bullet_summary: The joint Israeli-US strikes on Iran on Saturday targeted the Islamic republic's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and President Masoud Pezeshkian, Israel's public broadcaster reported
An unnamed Iranian official who spoke to the news agency said several ministries in southern Tehran had been targeted
Here is what we know so far about the attack, which the Israeli military said has been months in the making
US president Donald Trump said a ‚Äúmajor combat operation‚Äù against Iran had begun as he called for the country‚Äôs government to be overthrown

items.title: What we know about the joint US-Israel attack on Iran
items.standfirst: Iran has retaliated with a missile barrage towards Israel, while explosions have been heard in Qatar, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE.
items.content: Iran has retaliated with a missile barrage towards Israel, while explosions have been heard in Qatar, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE.

items.title: What we know about the joint US-Israeli air strikes on Iran
items.standfirst: The US and Israel on Saturday launched a wave of air strikes against Iran, targeting what Israel said were dozens of military sites as well as the compound housing Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, whose whereabouts remain unknown. Here is what we know so far about the attack, which the Israeli military said has been months in the making.
items.content: The US and Israel on Saturday launched a wave of air strikes against Iran, targeting what Israel said were dozens of military sites as well as the compound housing Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, whose whereabouts remain unknown. Here is what we know so far about the attack, which the Israeli military said has been months in the making.

items.title: Trump says US aims to destroy Iran's military, topple government
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump announced a major attack against Iran on Saturday, vowing to "annihilate" the country's navy and missile sites, and urging Iranians to overthrow their government.
items.content: US President Donald Trump announced a major attack against Iran on Saturday, vowing to "annihilate" the country's navy and missile sites, and urging Iranians to overthrow their government.

items.title: Donald Trump says US will destroy Iran missile
items.standfirst: U.S. President Donald Trump said in an 8-minute video posted on his Truth Social that the U.S. has begun ‚Äúmajor combat operations in Iran.‚Äù He claimed Iran has continued to develop its nuclear program and plans to develop missiles to reach U.S. and appealed to the Iranian people to ‚Äútake over your government.‚Äù
items.content: U.S. President Donald Trump said in an 8-minute video posted on his Truth Social that the U.S. has begun ‚Äúmajor combat operations in Iran.‚Äù He claimed Iran has continued to develop its nuclear program and plans to develop missiles to reach U.S. and appealed to the Iranian people to ‚Äútake over your government.‚Äù

items.title: Trump's Iran attack is a gamble and no one knows what might come next
items.standfirst: Donald Trump's decision to launch "major combat operations" in Iran is the biggest gamble by any American president since George Bush invaded Iraq more than two decades ago.
items.content: Donald Trump's decision to launch "major combat operations" in Iran is the biggest gamble by any American president since George Bush invaded Iraq more than two decades ago.

items.title: Why did the U.S. and Israel strike Iran? #world
items.standfirst: What happened and why it matters In the early hours of the reported operation, U.S. and Israeli forces carried out coordinated strikes on targets inside Iran, including apparent hits near Tehran. The White House said American military forces had begun what it called "major combat operations"‚Ä¶

The White House said American military forces had begun what it called "major combat operations"‚Ä¶

items.title: How advanced is Iran's nuclear program? Here's what we know.
items.standfirst: President Trump launched military strikes on Iran after several rounds of talks over the country's nuclear program and uranium stockpiles. Here's what to know about the nuclear program.
items.content: President Trump launched military strikes on Iran after several rounds of talks over the country's nuclear program and uranium stockpiles. Here's what to know about the nuclear program.

items.title: US and Israel launch strikes on Iran: what we know so far
items.standfirst: The US and Israel have attacked Iran, with Trump calling the US operation ‚Äòmassive and ongoing‚Äô. This is what we know so farIsrael and US attack Iran ‚Äì latest updatesFull reportThe US has launched ‚Äúmajor combat operations‚Äù in Iran, designed to eliminate ‚Äúimminent threats‚Äù from the country‚Äôs regime, Donald Trump announced on Saturday.The operation is ‚Äúmassive and ongoing‚Äù, the US president said in a video on social media, pledging to use ‚Äúoverwhelming strength and devastating force‚Äù to destroy Iranian missiles and ensure it cannot develop a nuclear weapon.The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said the attacks aimed to ‚Äúremove the existential threat‚Äù posed by the Iranian regime, as he urged the people of Iran to topple the government.Shortly beforehand, Israel said it had launched ‚Äúpreventative‚Äù strikes on Iran.The Israel Defense Forces said Iran had fired back a ‚Äúbarrage of missiles‚Äù and they were working to intercept them. Israel has closed its airspace.Explosions were heard in Tehran, the Iranian capital, where smoke could be seen rising on the skyline, and several other cities. Iran has closed its airspace.‚ÄúThe hour of your freedom is at hand,‚Äù Trump told Iranian citizens, urging them to ‚Äútake over your government‚Äù once the operation was over.Talks between the US and Iran on Tehran‚Äôs nuclear programme ended inconclusively on Friday, with a suggestion that further discussions would be held next week. Trump had said he was ‚Äúnot happy‚Äù with the progress of the discussions.Iran‚Äôs supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, is not in Tehran, and has been transferred to a secure location, an official told Reuters on Saturday. Continue reading...
items.content: The US and Israel have attacked Iran, with Trump calling the US operation ‚Äòmassive and ongoing‚Äô. This is what we know so farIsrael and US attack Iran ‚Äì latest updatesFull reportThe US has launched ‚Äúmajor combat operations‚Äù in Iran, designed to eliminate ‚Äúimminent threats‚Äù from the country‚Äôs regime, Donald Trump announced on Saturday.The operation is ‚Äúmassive and ongoing‚Äù, the US president said in a video on social media, pledging to use ‚Äúoverwhelming strength and devastating force‚Äù to destroy Iranian missiles and ensure it cannot develop a nuclear weapon.The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said the attacks aimed to ‚Äúremove the existential threat‚Äù posed by the Iranian regime, as he urged the people of Iran to topple the government.Shortly beforehand, Israel said it had launched ‚Äúpreventative‚Äù strikes on Iran.The Israel Defense Forces said Iran had fired back a ‚Äúbarrage of missiles‚Äù and they were working to intercept them. Israel has closed its airspace.Explosions were heard in Tehran, the Iranian capital, where smoke could be seen rising on the skyline, and several other cities. Iran has closed its airspace.‚ÄúThe hour of your freedom is at hand,‚Äù Trump told Iranian citizens, urging them to ‚Äútake over your government‚Äù once the operation was over.Talks between the US and Iran on Tehran‚Äôs nuclear programme ended inconclusively on Friday, with a suggestion that further discussions would be held next week. Trump had said he was ‚Äúnot happy‚Äù with the progress of the discussions.Iran‚Äôs supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, is not in Tehran, and has been transferred to a secure location, an official told Reuters on Saturday. Continue reading...

items.title: Watch: Trump's full statement on U.S. strikes against Iran
items.standfirst: President Trump announced early Saturday morning that the U.S. is conducting "a massive and ongoing operation to prevent this very wicked, radical dictatorship from threatening America and our core national security interests." See his full remarks.
items.content: President Trump announced early Saturday morning that the U.S. is conducting "a massive and ongoing operation to prevent this very wicked, radical dictatorship from threatening America and our core national security interests." See his full remarks.

items.title: U.S. and Israel launch strikes against Iran | Special Report
items.standfirst: The U.S. and Israel carried out military strikes on targets in Iran early Saturday after President Trump threatened the Iranian regime for weeks to make a new deal to rein in its nuclear program, and before that, threatened it over its violent crackdown on protesters in January. Carissa Lawson anchors CBS News' special report.
items.content: The U.S. and Israel carried out military strikes on targets in Iran early Saturday after President Trump threatened the Iranian regime for weeks to make a new deal to rein in its nuclear program, and before that, threatened it over its violent crackdown on protesters in January. Carissa Lawson anchors CBS News' special report.

items.title: Watch: Trump says U.S. military has begun "major combat operations in Iran"
items.standfirst: President Trump said the U.S. military has begun "major combat operations in Iran" in a statement released early Saturday morning. Mr. Trump threatened the Iranian regime for weeks to make a new deal to rein in its nuclear program, and before that, threatened it over its violent crackdown on protesters in January.
items.content: President Trump said the U.S. military has begun "major combat operations in Iran" in a statement released early Saturday morning. Mr. Trump threatened the Iranian regime for weeks to make a new deal to rein in its nuclear program, and before that, threatened it over its violent crackdown on protesters in January.

items.title: Live: Iran fires retaliatory missiles at Israel, US bases after air strikes
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said on Saturday that Washington had begun "major combat operations" in Iran after Israel and the United States launched a joint attack on the Islamic Republic Saturday. Tehran announced it is preparing to retaliate in response to the operation that an Israeli defence official said had been planned for months. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

clusters.title: Anthropic CEO says he's sticking to AI "red lines" despite clash with Pentagon
clusters.neutral_headline: OpenAI strikes deal with Pentagon to use tech in ‚Äòclassified network‚Äô
bullet_summary: How the agreement came together and why it matters OpenAI announced it has reached an arrangement to deploy its models inside a Defense Department classified network
In an exclusive interview with CBS News, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said that the Pentagon's decision to designate the AI company a supply chain risk is "retaliatory and punitive
The move announced on social media comes after a standoff between Anthropic's boss and the US Department of Defense
President Trump said he will give federal agencies six months to phase out their use of Anthropic's AI products

items.title: Anthropic CEO says he's sticking to AI "red lines" despite clash with Pentagon

The dispute‚Ä¶

items.title: What did OpenAI agree with the DOD? #tech
items.standfirst: Permission to run in classified environments with safety strings attached OpenAI reached an agreement with the Department of War to deploy its models inside a classified DOD network. The deal allows the agency to use OpenAI‚Äôs technology for some classified workflows while preserving constraints‚Ä¶
items.content: Permission to run in classified environments with safety strings attached OpenAI reached an agreement with the Department of War to deploy its models inside a classified DOD network. The deal allows the agency to use OpenAI‚Äôs technology for some classified workflows while preserving constraints‚Ä¶

items.title: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei calls White House's actions "retaliatory and punitive"
items.standfirst: Hours before Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei's interview, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth deemed the AI company a "supply chain risk to national security," which restricts military contractors from doing business with Anthropic.
items.content: Hours before Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei's interview, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth deemed the AI company a "supply chain risk to national security," which restricts military contractors from doing business with Anthropic.

items.title: Anthropic CEO on "retaliatory and punitive" Pentagon action
items.standfirst: In an exclusive interview with CBS News, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said that the Pentagon's decision to designate the AI company a supply chain risk is "retaliatory and punitive." The Pentagon made the designation, which restricts military contractors from doing business with Anthropic, after the company refused to give the military unfettered access to its AI model.
items.content: In an exclusive interview with CBS News, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said that the Pentagon's decision to designate the AI company a supply chain risk is "retaliatory and punitive." The Pentagon made the designation, which restricts military contractors from doing business with Anthropic, after the company refused to give the military unfettered access to its AI model.

items.title: Anthropic CEO on "red lines" for AI military use: "We wanted to stand up for American values"
items.standfirst: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said in an exclusive interview with CBS News that the AI company sought to draw "red lines" in the government's use of its technology because "we believe that crossing those lines is contrary to American values, and we wanted to stand up for American values." He added: "Disagreeing with the government is the most American thing in the world."
items.content: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said in an exclusive interview with CBS News that the AI company sought to draw "red lines" in the government's use of its technology because "we believe that crossing those lines is contrary to American values, and we wanted to stand up for American values." He added: "Disagreeing with the government is the most American thing in the world."

items.title: Trump orders US agencies to stop use of Anthropic technology amid dispute over ethics of AI
items.standfirst: Hours after exclusion of Anthropic, OpenAI announces fresh Pentagon deal, but says it will maintain same safety guardrails at the heart of the dispute Sign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxDonald Trump said Friday he will direct all federal agencies to ‚ÄúIMMEDIATELY CEASE‚Äù all use of Anthropic technology in the latest instalment of a very public clash over AI safety.The Department of Defense and Anthropic hit an impasse with neither side backing down as a deadline for an agreement lapsed on Friday afternoon. The Pentagon had demanded the artificial intelligence company loosen ethical guidelines on its AI systems or face severe consequences. Continue reading...

The Pentagon had demanded the artificial intelligence company loosen ethical guidelines on its AI systems or face severe consequences. Continue reading...

items.title: At least 20 killed as cash-laden military cargo plane crashes in Bolivia
items.standfirst: Riot police use teargas to disperse people gathering around wreckage of plane loaded with money from central bankAt least 20 people have died and dozens have been injured after a military cargo plane carrying banknotes crashed while landing near Bolivia‚Äôs capital on Friday, damaging about a dozen vehicles on a highway and scattering bills on the ground, an official has said.Footage from local media showed people rushing to collect banknotes while police in riot gear tried to disperse them using teargas. items.title: Trump says 'not happy' with Iran talks, but undecided on possible military action
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he was "not happy" with the way Iran was negotiating in talks with the US, but had not yet made a "final decision" on whether the US would launch military action against Tehran. His comments came as the US advised its non-emergency embassy staff to leave Israel "due to safety risks".
items.content: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he was "not happy" with the way Iran was negotiating in talks with the US, but had not yet made a "final decision" on whether the US would launch military action against Tehran. His comments came as the US advised its non-emergency embassy staff to leave Israel "due to safety risks".
